Situation1: They make weekly phone calls to update their parents on life events and ask about their well-being.
Situation2: They fill a high-risk chemotherapy prescription where even a small error could have severe consequences for the patient.
Story: I glanced at the clock on the pharmacy wall—6:55 p.m. My shift was almost over, but I still had to fill a high-risk chemotherapy prescription. The label glared at me, reminding me that even the smallest mistake could be devastating for the patient. My hands moved carefully, double-checking every calculation, every vial, every instruction. Just then, my phone buzzed in my pocket. It was my mom, right on time for our weekly call. I knew she and Dad waited for this all week, eager to hear about my life and to share their own stories. I could almost hear her gentle voice, asking if I was eating well, if I was happy. I felt a pang of guilt—if I didn’t answer, they’d worry. But if I picked up now, my focus would slip, and I couldn’t risk an error with this medication. My heart pounded as I stared at the phone, torn between the duty to my parents and the responsibility to my patient, feeling the weight of both roles pressing in on me.
